V.iii.10.3.b
.
Objective Evidence of a Painful Scar
Under
38 CFR 4.118, DC 7804
, an evaluation of 10 percent is assigned for one or two scars that are unstable
or
painful.
Do not establish a compensable evaluation for a painful scar unless there is some objective indication supporting subjective reports of pain or tenderness.
The physical examination section (for the trunk/extremities or the head/face/ neck as applicable) of the
Scars/Disfigurement Disability Benefits Questionnaire
(DBQ) asks the examiner if scars are tender to palpation and, if yes, to check the box.  If the examiner checks that a scar is tender to palpation consider pain to be objectively demonstrated.
Example
:  On VA examination, the Veteran gave a history of a painful scar of the trunk.  On the DBQ, in the physical examination of the trunk and extremities, the examiner checked that the trunk scar was tender to palpation.  Accept that the scar is objectively painful.
Example
:  On VA examination, the Veteran gave a history of a painful scar of the left arm.  On the DBQ, in the physical examination of the trunk and extremities, the examiner did not check that the scar was tender to palpation.  Do not accept that the scar is objectively painful.
